threats.title: Developer commits secret to Git
threats.description:
A developer commits secrets to version control either
accidentally or on purpose. An angry employee with read access to the
repository finds the secrets and proceeds to use them to steal end-user
data.
threats.mitigation:
• Use something like git-secrets in repositories to help detect, flag, and block merge
requests which may contain secrets
• Ensure the company is using secure secret management techniques such as tools
like Hashicorp Vault
• Ensure secrets are stored encrypted at rest
• Adhere to the principal of "Need to Know" and ensure that production secrets are
not shared with individuals who don't have a need to know
• Adhere to the principal of "Least Privilege" and ensure secrets only have the the
permissions to fulfill their use case
• Ensure logging is enabled so that secret usage can be tracked to the system and/or
user who acquired and used them
• Ensure version control system is only available on the corporate VPN

threats.title: Cloning & Manipulating GitHub
threats.description: Adversaries may inject malicious code directly into exposed libraries or submit fraudulent pull requests, introducing backdoors, executing code injection attacks, or leverage proof-of-concept code. Attackers have been seen cloning GitHub repositories and adding malicious code to forks designed to infect developer systems and sensitive files that included software keys.
threats.mitigation:
• Regularly updating and patching dependencies is critical for addressing known vulnerabilities and security issues. 
• Security defenders are also advised to stay informed on emerging security alerts providing updates related to third-party libraries used by their organisations.
• Software composition analysis (SCA) tools can enhance security by scanning repositories for vulnerable dependencies and automating remediation or flagging issues for manual review.

threats.title: Insecure Dependencies and Libraries
threats.description: Libraries that are not up-to-date or from unverified sources might contain potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited by malicious individuals.
threats.mitigation:
• Regularly updating third-party libraries and dependencies helps to patch security vulnerabilities and ensure the use of the latest features.
• Ensuring the authenticity and integrity of third-party libraries before integrating them into the pipeline safeguards against supply chain attacks.
• Relying only on reputable and trusted sources for third-party libraries reduces the likelihood of introducing malicious code.

threats.title: Abuse of GitHub Actions & CI/CD Pipelines
threats.description: Threat actors can exploit GitHub’s continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines and automation features, such as GitHub Actions, to automate malicious activities and orchestrate attacks. By leveraging these capabilities, attackers deploy malware, exfiltrate data, or execute unauthorised commands within CI/CD workflows.
threats.mitigation:
• Enforce least privilege access controls to restrict the execution of CI/CD workflows and automation scripts and reduce the attack surface. 
• Pre-defined templates and secure coding practices can also help prevent injection attacks and unauthorised code execution.
• Security teams may also adopt logging and auditing features in order to more thoroughly track changes and activities within CI/CD pipelines.

threats.title: Tampering application codes at Docker Hub
threats.description: The application code may be tampered with by attackers to include vulnerabilities. It can result in the attacker accessing a user’s application image and tamper with its codes. If the image is not signed, the change will not be detected during download. In addition, Docker images may contain inherent vulnerabilities which the developers are not aware of until they are deployed in a production environment.
threats.mitigation:
• Enforce strong password,  two-factor authentication or multi factor  authentication.
• It is recommended that an image be kept minimal so that the attack surfaces can be reduced.
• It is advised that a developer digitally sign image with Docker Content Trust that is attached to the 
   Notary server, which is used for validating the integrity of the images.
• Keep Docker images secure with regular vulnerability scans.

threats.title: Compromised admin access
threats.description: Compromised admin access to a CI/CD Pipeline account can lead to a variety of threats such as execution and lateral movement, and software supply chain attacks. Attackers may use techniques like creating additional local accounts to maintain their foothold.
threats.mitigation:
• Minimize the use of long-term credentials. 
• Utilise two-person rules (2PR) for all code updates.
• Secure user accounts.
• Implement least-privilege policies for CI/CD access.
